responses.content:
```yaml
leads:
  - headline: Sensitive information disclosure in gruntfile.js
    analysis: |
      The file `gruntfile.js` appears to contain sensitive information, including local file paths and possibly even private keys.
      If this file is ever committed to a public repository, that information would be publicly accessible. An attacker could leverage it
      to gain further access to the development environment, or even to production environments depending on how closely they are
      integrated.
    cwe: CWE-200
    function_names: []
    filenames:
      - gruntfile.js
    classification: slightly promising
  - headline: Potential Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) via arbitrary URL in `browserSync` configuration
    analysis: |
      The `browserSync` configuration in `gruntfile.js` uses a hardcoded `proxy` value of "https://dev.wordpress.dev".  If an attacker
      could control this value, they might be able to make the server initiate requests to arbitrary URLs, leading to potential SSRF.
    cwe: CWE-918
    function_names: []
    filenames:
      - gruntfile.js
    classification: not promising
```

leads.headline: Sensitive information disclosure in gruntfile.js
leads.analysis:
The file gruntfile.js appears to contain sensitive information, including local file paths and possibly even private keys.
If this file is ever committed to a public repository, that information would be publicly accessible. An attacker could leverage it
to gain further access to the development environment, or even to production environments depending on how closely they are
integrated.

leads.headline: Potential Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) via arbitrary URL in browserSync configuration
leads.analysis:
The browserSync configuration in gruntfile.js uses a hardcoded proxy value of "https://dev.wordpress.dev".  If an attacker
could control this value, they might be able to make the server initiate requests to arbitrary URLs, leading to potential SSRF.
